creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Does it hurt anything for Apache to treat these as 1.0?
"Be lenient in what you accept", right?

but what are specs for if we don't care about them ?

RFC says "HTTP" / 1*DIGIT . 1*DIGIT where DIGITI is "0" .. "9"
creator: bzeeb@zabbadoz.net
slive@apache.org
text:
That's not a good argument.  Specs are there to facilitate interoperability
of software, not to inhibit it.

There probably are good arguments for being more restrictive here, but I'll
leave that question to others.

creator: bzeeb@zabbadoz.net
text:
Ok, one other point:

as long as one can write %s %d ... to logfiles p.ex.
"GET / HTTP/%s%s.%d"

it is also possible to "confuse" log analizers programs.

As Steve Grubb had pointed out p.ex. on bugtraq.vuln-dev along with the
"Apache 2.x leaked descriptors" problem:
"In the past, there have been vulnerable versions of these programs."

creator: jorton@redhat.com
text:
I don't see any good motivation to change this behaviour; the default to be
lenient seems reasonable.  The r->the_request string can already contain valid
format printf strings (URI %-escapes) so log analysers do already have to be
robust against that.
